cPool.sectionText:
A normal ostomy output is anything less than 1 litre (1000ml) of fluid over a 24 hour period. An output higher than 1 litre per day is considered a high output. High ostomy outputs are typically very watery and need frequent emptying.

  • High outputs are more common in small bowel (ileostomy or jejunostomy) compared to large bowel (colostomy) ostomies.
  • This handout will provide you with some suggestions on how to manage high outputs through diet modification.
  • If diet does not help, you may need to discuss a medication with your physician.
  • If your outputs are high, you are at a greater risk for dehydration as well as sodium and potassium losses.
Food and fluid suggestions to reduce stoma output:
  • Avoid foods that may increase stoma output( see the list of foods that increase stoma output)
  • Try to include foods that thicken stoma output (See the list of foods that thicken and decrease stoma output).
  • Chew food very well.
  • Eat regular meals. Try eating 6 small meals per day versus 3 large meals.
  • Add extra salt to your meals or include salty snacks (i.e. chips, crackers etc.). Given the loss of salt through the ostomy, you will need extra to help absorb liquids better.
  • Limit high sugar foods and beverages such as chocolate, honey, jams/jellies, liquorice, sweetened beverages. Avoid sweeteners such as sorbitol and mannitol. These are often found in chewing gums.
  • Try to include a low fibre starchy food (bread, potatoes, pasta, rice) and protein food (peanut butter, eggs, fish, chicken, meat).This will help to slow down the digestion of food through the bowel allowing more time for your body to digest and absorb.
  • Some people find it helpful to decrease the amount of lactose in their diet such as milk, yogurt, ice cream and other dairy products. The lactose sugar found in milk can sometimes cause higher outputs and bloating.
  • Separate solids from liquids: wait 30-45 minutes before or after eating to have your fluids. Limit fluids with meals to only sips and have no more than 125ml (1/2 cup) in total per meal. This helps to slow down the movement of food through the bowel to allow for better absorption of nutrients.
  • Limit your intake of all other types of fluids each day including water, tea, coffee, milk and juice to less than 500ml (2 cups) per day. Drink oral rehydration solutions throughout the day. Water, tea and coffee can increase your output. Oral rehydration solutions will help to replace the fluid and minerals (sodium and potassium) lost in high outputs to prevent dehydration and help absorb the fluid.

Recipes for oral rehydration solutions are given below (Try and sip on 1-3 L(depending on the stoma output) of oral rehydration solution throughout the day.

Homemade Recipes:

  • 2 cups (500ml) of Gatorade
  • 2 cups (500ml) water
  • ½ tsp salt
    • Mix above ingredients and drink.
  • 600ml of Powerade
  • 600ml of water
  • 1 tsp of salt
    • Mix above ingredients and drink.
Double strength Gastrolyte
  • 2 Sachets of gastrolyte
  • 200ml water
    • Mix above ingredients and drink.
St Mark’s solution
  • 6 heaped 5ml teaspoons glucose
  • 1 level 5ml teaspoon salt
  • Half heaped 2.5ml teaspoon sodium bicarbonate
  • Stir all ingredients into 1litre of water and chill overnight before consuming.
    • You can add a small amount of diet cordial to improve the taste.

Foods that may increase the stoma output:

  • Alcoholic beverages
  • Beverages that have caffeine such as coffee, tea and cola
  • Spicy foods
  • Dried fruit and pineapple
  • Juice especially apple, grape and prune
  • Nuts, seeds
  • Olives, Pickles
  • Peas, corn, legumes
  • Popcorn
  • Skins and seeds of fruit and vegetables
  • Wholegrain breads and cereals
  • High sugar foods such as Chocolate, Honey, Jams, Jellies Liquorice

Foods that may thicken up the stoma output:

  • Applesauce
  • Bananas
  • Bread – white
  • Cheese
  • Oat bran
  • Oatmeal
  • Pasta – white
  • Peanut butter – smooth
  • Potatoes
  • Pretzels
  • Rice pudding
  • Boiled white Rice
  • Tapioca
  • Marshmallow

References:

  • Dietitians of Canada: PEN topic Ostomy
  • DAA DINER: Nutritional Management of High output stomas; Sharon Carey, Deputy Manager and Gastro dietitian, Royal Prince Alfred Hospital
  • Nutrition Manual; Dietitians Association Of Australia, Western Australia Branch, Seventh Edition 2004
